The Ashes 2025/2026

History in the Making!

Anticipation, excitement, trepidation or whatever your emotions are ahead of the Ashes as an England fan, let’s hope the series finally delivers a highly competitive spectacle for the first time since 2011 in Australia. England will hope the Test Series gets off to a positive start in Perth before the Australians have the opportunity to assert their dominance in pink ball tests at The Gabba. If it’s 1-1 after two Tests we could be in for quite the memorable series.

The name of The Ashes comes from Australia’s victory over England at The Oval in 1882. The Sporting Times dubbed the defeat for England the death of English Cricket and that "the body will be cremated and the ashes taken to Australia".

Players To Watch

Steve Smith

The Australian great will likey play in his last Ashes series where he will be 36 years-old. The former captain has an amazing record against England and will surely relish the opportunity to help his team retain the urn. Smith’s place in the side is not a certainty but it is hard to argue they are a better side without him in it despite his batting average declining in recent years. His test century in the series against India showed all his guts and battle and he is not a player England will look forward to bowling at.

Last updated 3 mins ago
Brydon Carse

The 29 year-old South African born seamer has catapulted himself to the forefront of England’s plans for the Ashes. In September 2024, many would not have been certain he would be in the squad but after a staggering start to his Test career firstly in Pakistan and more recently in New Zealand, he looks likely to lead the England attack. He has taken 27 wickets in five tests with a best of 6-42. He bowls with good pace and in the early stages of his international career has proved a player England can rely on whose technique should suit Australian pitches.

Last updated 3 mins ago
